projects.title: PlaceNotes
projects.desc: PlaceNotes was a position based note-taking application for iOS. A note was tied to the place where it was made, and could then only be accessed from that place. Use cases might include making notes of yummy dishes at restaurants, keeping track of PRs at the gym, or taking notes at work that you don't want to be stressed about at home.

projects.title: Saturn
projects.desc: Saturn was a game designed to broaden your taste in music. The game was based on a timeline, and guessing where on the timeline, or rather in which timespan, different songs belong. Answering correctly places the year on the timeline, and another time span is added, so the more correct answers, the trickier it gets to guess the next one.

projects.title: Ecomon
projects.desc: Ecomon was a service that uses gamification to get users to be more aware of their energy consumtion by rewarding points based on actions the user takes. During the project, a REST API was developed, along with a web app and an Android app that uses said API.

projects.title: Catastrophy
projects.desc: Catastrophy is a game made in Unity during a hackathon. You play as a ball of yarn, and your objective is to bounce away from a hungry kitten.

projects.title: Lära
projects.desc: Lära is a business idea and concept for a crowdsourced knowledge platform, where anyone can create courses for others to take. Integrated in the platform would be a Pay-What-You-Want payment system, where users pay whatever they feel something is worth. A very simple web prototype was created for this concept.

projects.title: Designing Mobile Permission Prompts
projects.desc: I wrote a paper for a student conference, researching mobile permission prompts. The paper analyses the current use of permission prompts, and suggests to reformulate the permission prompts to better inform users about why permissions are needed.

projects.title: Artnet
projects.desc: Artnet is a prototype of an Android application designed to get more people interested in arts and culture. If the user is close to an artpiece or a museum, he or she gets a notification to check in and rate it in the app, and depending on what type of cultural genre it is, the user builds their cultural profile, gets profile based achievements, and shares their cultural journey with friends.

projects.title: DateMe
projects.desc: DateMe is a dating service that allows users who are close enough to chat with eachother. During the project, a web REST API was developed, along with a web app, and an Android app that uses that API.

projects.title: Hashtagz
projects.desc: Hashtagz is a mashup app that uses the APIs for Instagram, 500px and Flickr to display images based on a search query for hashtags.

projects.title: Glass Emulator
projects.desc: A simple and web based emulator for Google Glass that allows the user to prototype cards on Glass.

projects.title: Learn with (Google) Glass
projects.desc: A homework service that uses a web interface where teachers can create lessons and challenges with image, audio, video and text. These lessons are then sent to Glass, which the students use to solve the challenges.

projects.title: SmartOffice
projects.desc: A smart and ubiquitous office environment, prototyped with scissors and cardboard. The concept includes face recognition for entering the office, a welcoming screen by the door that displays relevant information based on who's accessing it, automatic windows and lights in the conference room, etc.

projects.title: Jamspot
projects.desc: Jamspot was an application that used NFC tags to store, keep and display music, developed at the Unify hackathon at Spotify in 2015. The concept is to tag Spotify playlists to NFC tags on a map, to store memories from previous travels, for travel agencies to share some native tunes with potential travelers, etc.

projects.title: Mini-CMS
projects.desc: A Mini-CMS that my previous website was built on, and which was limited to producing blog posts and project posts. These chould include images and tags, and had markdown for formatting the posts. Made with Ruby on Rails.
